newsitem.title: FRANCE: Jospin - French govt to review law on layoffs.
newsitem.headline: Jospin - French govt to review law on layoffs.

text.p: Prime Minister Lionel Jospin said on Thursday he had asked the labour ministry to review layoffs laws.
He said he expected to propose changes to the laws to prevent situations like the planned closure of Renault's Vilvoorde plant.

"I have asked the minister of labour and solidarity to reexamine legislation on layoffs for economic reasons, with the aim of preventing it from leading to insecurity for workers and legal uncertainty for companies," Jospin said in a keynote address to parliament.
"Based on the report, the government will present draft legislation to parliament," Jospin said.

"From the time I arrived, I was confronted with the consequences of the Vilvoorde conflict. I do not want to see this situation reproduced. Job-cutting plans should be a last resort after the end of genuine negotiations," he said.

Renault provoked an outcry in February when it announced plans to close the Belgian assembly plant that employed 3,100 people. After the arrival of the new government, Renault, 46 percent state-owned, appointed an independent expert to review the decision.
"I said it during the campaign. I repeat it today. Jobs are our priority," Jospin said.
